STUDENT LIFE AT EDINBURGH.
I.
In the university city of Edinburgh a "Town
and Gown Association" was formed in the
year 1896 for co-operative undertakings in the
joint interest of citizens and students. It was
for the common good of city and university.
The Association is a stock company representing academic interests for the purpose of providing residential halls or house accommodation for students and other persons connected
either with the University or with the liberal
professions. Although Edinburgh University
has been in existence for more than two centuries, it has never enjoyed the benefit of college
halls or hostels like those which have given
such architectural character and social charm
to Oxford and Cambridge. Students and professors have lived in Edinburgh wherever they
could find lodgings. There has been no real
unity to academic life, no college centre or
Latin Quarter, where students live and educate
one another in their own society—perhaps the
most effective of all academic means of culture.
The English colleges have always been strong
in social education, but here the Scotch and
German universities are weak.
To remedy a long-standing and manifest defect in Edinburgh student life the Town and
Gown Association was organized by the
energy and enterprise of Professor Patrick
Geddes, who lives near the Outlook Tower on
Castle Hill and surveys from his charming
apartments, at the top of an airy citadel, the
historic City of Edinburgh and the picturesque
country round about. While Professor Geddes
has had in mind the need of better associated
collegiate life in Edinburgh, he has also sought
the material and architectural improvement of
the city. It is well known by all visitors to this
ancient capital of Scotland that the historic and

No. 3

picturesque old town, extending from Castle
Hill eastward to Holyrood, was until lately the
most dilapidated and unsanitary part of the city.
Municipal and architectural improvements,
which Professor Geddes has greatly promoted,
have now transformed some of the worst of
'those ancient rookeries, narrow passageways
and noisome courts into spacious college halls
and modern apartment houses.
The beginnings of this remarkable movement, which is at once "civic and academic,
architectural and educational," date from the
year 1887. Then a new social life was instituted for students in Edinburgh by the renting
and furnishing of three small flats on the socalled "Mound," which connects Old and New
Town. At first only seven students entered
upon this common or associated life ; but the
number increased and soon an entire house was
needed to supply the demand. By a perfectly
natural law of growth, and upon a sound business basis, the first residential hall in Edinburgh was established. It is now a studenthome for members of New College. In 1890
another house WaS purchased in Riddle's court
and reconstructed for student-residents. In
the same year was acquired an historic locality
once occupied by the Scotch poet, Allan Ramsay, author of "The Gentle Shepherd." Gradually a range of new houses was built on two
sides of Ramsay Garden, so that now there is a
large number of comfortable flats, or sets of
chambers, occupied by professors and their
families, and a large building called "Ramsay
Lodge," with numerous rooms, occupied by
students in residence.
The visitor in Edinburgh as he strolls along
Princes street (said to be, for noble views, the
finest street in Europe) will find himself looking upwards to that natural acropolis where
"Edwin's Burgh" gave name and fame to the
Old Town on the hill. Extending eastward
from the castle and the walls of the Esplanade

THE NEWS-LETTER.
NEWS OF A FORTNIGHT.
CONORESSIVE SESSION.

The first regular meeting of the Senate,
which was held November 3, was honored by
the presence of Dean Griffin, who expressed
himself as much pleased with the work. The
meeting proved how much practice in debating
is needed by the Senators. Several of the debaters were seized with stage fright, and found
it difficult to speak without stumbling over
words and making awkward pauses. This fault
is common to all beginners, and will surely disappear with practice. Time that might have
been used in debate was lost in calling the roll
and reading the minutes of the previous meeting. Hereafter the roll will be taken silently—
that is, the clerk will simply mark the absence
of members without calling the names. The
minutes will be referred to the Censor. In this
way it will be possible to begin the debate five
minutes after opening the session. As the Senate ages, the members will settle to their work,
and the slight breaches of decorum that mar
the proceedings of any forensic body will be
eliminated. On the whole, the first meeting
of the Senate may be pronounced a success.
The current debate was won by the affirmative,
represented by Messrs. Lucke, Renouf and E.
Smith.
The subject for the next debate is:
"Resolved, That the result of the work of the
present United States Bimetallic Commission
ought to definitely settle the discussion of the
'Silver Question.'"
Senators Fisher, Fitzgerald and R. D. Miller have the affirmative ; Senators Ballard,
Whitehead and Cook the negative.
The first regular meeting of the House of
Representatives was held Wednesday, October 26. Speaker French presided. The use of
a gavel, a valuable old Indian relic, was tendered to the House by Dr. Adams. The Censor announced that Dr. Adams had also given
the use of the Southern History room for the
debaters. The House moved that a vote of
thanks be given to Dr. Adams. The main interest of the meeting centered in the debate :

3

"Resolved, That municipal government be independent of national party lines." The affirmative was taken by Messrs. Smull, Jones,
Ver Planck and M. Jungbluth ; the negative
by Messrs. Mullen, Grimes, Gemmil and Joyner. The House decided on the merits of the
debaters that the negative side had won. The
debate for next time was given to Congressmen Fosnocht, Frank and Greenbaum for the
negative, and Congressmen Levering, Kalb
and Gaddess for the affirmative. In parliamentary law the following appointments were
made: Leader of attack, H. Grimes; leader
of defense, C. Remsen.

nusicAL CLUB'S CONCERT.
The University Banjo and Mandolin Clubs
gave the first concert of the season on Friday
evening, November 5, at Hannah More Academy, near Reisterstown. The trip was made
on a special car over the new Baltimore and
Northern Electric Railroad.
The occasion of the concert was the opening
of Wyman Hall, which was filled by a large audience drawn from Baltimore, Pikesville and
Reisterstown. The clubs played well and were
heartily received by the audience. The new
men give promise of ranking among the best
players in the clubs, and there is no reason
why, under the leadership of Mr. Peters and
with a full attendance at practice, this year's
clubs should not excel those of '93-'94 and
'96-'97, the best in the history of Hopkins.
Mr. Harwood and Mr. Clunet made a great
hit with their new songs.
The vocal parts were ably given by Miss
Starr, the composer of the music of "Veritas
Vos Liberabit," and Mr. Frank Taylor, the
well-known soloist of the club. Mr. Edwin L.
Turnbull gave two selections on the violin.
After the concert there was dancing, kept
up until the men were compelled to leave, carrying with them pleasant memories of the hospitality of Hannah More.
Dr. Hollander, of the Economic Department, has just returned from Europe, where
he served as secretary of the Bimetallic Commission.

TRAINING AND HONOR.
NEW ATHLETIC ASSOCIATION.

One of the best efforts in athletics at Hopkins is the proposed reorganization of the Athletic Association. Up to the present time the
several other athletic societies which have been
independent of it have amounted to nothing.
Each one is simply a name. It is true that they
do choose officials for the teams, but even this
they sometimes do most unwisely. It is a palpable blunder for a body of several delegates to
elect the leader of a team. The team itself
should choose the captain. Another serious
defect in the several associations was that there
was no business responsibility and no authority. In short the manager was the association,
with all rights and abuses thereto appertaining.
The new association should have a constitut.ion which provides for a strong centralization,
and the alumni should be represented. By
bringing all departments of sport under one
government there is the advantage of having a
reliable organization to guide the teams and
the managers. Then we should have such a
rarity as system. All that is necessary in the
association is a representative membership.
Two of the salient features proposed are the
election of the managers by the board of direct-

Unpleasant rumors are going about. It is
said that certain members of the football team
have been smoking. This is a deplorable state
of affairs. It is right for the students to
object. So long as the players keep in good
physical condition there will be sympathy and
support in case of defeat. But if the men do
not train they cannot expect to win, and they
deserve to be "roasted" by the students. We
hope that the reports of the violations of rules
are untrue. In training for a team the adherence to a pledge is a matter of honesty. There
is no absolute prevention if a man cares to
smoke or in any other way violate the rules.
The point to appreciate, then, is that honor is
just as necessary on the football team as in the
examination room, and a violator should be
treated accordingly.

It is interesting to note the prominent part
played in the late election by former Hopkins
students. One graduate, who, while a student
at the Hopkins, impressed everyone by his extremely retiring disposition, stumped New
York City for Low on street corners and from
the back of grocery wagons.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
!ATHLETICS.
ENTHUSIASTIC rtAss METING.
A mass-meeting of the students was held in
Hopkins Hall October 29 to discuss and consider the reorganization of the General Athletic Association. The assembly decided upon
two points, which, it is believed, will further
the interest of athletics at the University. An
effort will be made to centralize the several
athletic associations which now exist, each
under separate government, and, second, the
students will earnestly strive to procure a field.
President Edward Renouf was chairman
and Dr. J. B. Crenshaw was secretary. The
President discussed the situation of the separate organizations, and showed clearly that unless these associations were put under one head
athletics at the University could never have a
future.
At present there exist the Football Association, the Lacrosse Association, and the Baseball Association. Several speeches were made,
all proving that these several organizations
could no longer exist as such. It was shown
that the associations had done almost nothing
for athletics; that they were mere paper associations, and, beyond assembling for the annual
election of the managers and captains, did absolutely nothing. The responsibility rested
alone on these men, and, if debts were incurred, they alone received the blame.
To obviate this, it was decided that the President appoint a committee of seven students to
ascertain how the students felt on this point,
and to draw up a constitution for the proposed
reorganization.
The committee consists of J. 13. Crenshaw
(chairman), Hancock, Reese, Dieffenbach,
Scholl,'Grimes, G. C. Robinson and Foster.
The heavy beams which will support the
roof of the cage are in position and the building now gives an idea of what it will be when
finished. It will require only a few weeks to
complete the structure. The gymnasium will
not be ready for occupancy so early on account of the interior work.

VICTORIES AT GEORGETOWN.

Johns Hopkins won two events and got second place in another at the Georgetown games
on Saturday. Robert Garrett was the chief attraction of the day, and his feat with the
discus brought out much applause. Scholl
won the high jump, Garrett won at discusthrowing,and was second in the running broad
jump. Knapp was put in a preliminary heat
with Wefers, champion of the world, in the
ioo-yard dash, and failed to qualify in the
final. In the discus event Garrett did not exert
himself, and won easily at 107 feet 7 inches.
Scholl cleared 5 feet 5 inches in the high jump
in good form. In the running broad jump the
measuring was decidedly favorable to Georgetown. When Garrett and Scholl jumped the
tape was drawn taut, but the home competitor,
Walsh, was given a slack tape twisted several
times. The event was nevertheless a notable
one, for Garrett broke the Maryland record
made by him-2I feet 91 inches. He beat this
by an inch and a half. Scholl made 21 feet
inches, breaking his own record by eighteen
inches. Walsh was credited with 22 feet
inch. About forty rooters went over to cheer
on the men. Incidentally, they gave .the other
colleges represented a few pointers as to college yells.

IN THE LAND OF THE CZAR.
Dr. William B. Clark, professor of geology
in the Johns Hopkins University, has just returned from Russia, where he has been in attendance upon the International Geological
Congress in St. Petersburg. He bore the credentials of the Secretary of State as one of the
six national delegates from the United States,
and also an appointment from the Governor
of Maryland to represent the State as State
Geologist.
An international congress is held every three
years at one of the leading cities of the world,
the first congress being held in Paris in 1878.
Subsequent congresses have been held at Bologna, Berlin, London, Washington and Zurich. The invitation to hold the seventh Inter1Lati9nal Congress at St. Petersburg was presented in the name of the Czar by the Russian
representatives at the Washington Congress
in 1891, and was at once accepted by that Congress. Assurances were given of most cordial
welcome on the part of the Russian Government and people. How sincerely these assurances were meant is shown by the marvelous
hospitality with which the delegates to the International Congress at St. Petersburg were
greeted. Free tickets upon all Russian transportation lines were granted to the members of
the Congress, so that after reaching the borders of Russia no expenses for railway and
steamboat travel were incurred. Orders were
also given to the customs officials to pass the
members of the Congress without inconvenience.
The Congress opened upon August 29 in
St. Petersburg, with somewhat over 600 delegates in attendance, representatives being present from nearly every country of the world.
The Germans and French were much more
numerous than the representatives of other
countries. About forty American geologists
were present, among them the aged Professor
Hall, the State Geologist of New York; Professor Marsh, of Yale University, and Professor S. F. Emmons,of the United States Geological Survey.

7

Among the distinguished Europeans were
Sir Archibald Geikie, who lectured at the University on the Williams foundation last spring;
Baron von Richthofen, of Berlin; Prof. von
Zittel, of Munich ; Professor Zirkel, of Leipsic ; Professor Capellini, of Florence ; Professor Brogger, of Christiania, and many others.
The Congress was opened with an addres by
the Grand Duke Constantine, a cousin of the
Czar, and remained in session a week, during
which time the delegates were elaborately entertained, the Czar giving a great banquet in
honor of the Congress at Peterhof. The members of the Congress were also elaborately entertained by the Grand Duke Constantine, the
Governor of St. Petersburg, and the other
celebrities. During the session of the Congress
the members visited Finland at the invitation of
the Senate of that country, a day being spent at
the Falls of Imatra, where a state dinner was
given in honor of the visitors.
At the close of the Congress the members
went to Moscow, where, after a few days' visit
in that city, they divided into three groups,
each party journeying to Vladikavkaz at the
base of the Caucasus Mountains by different
routes. Professor Clark accompanied the
Volga party, going first to Nijni Novgorod,
where the great Russian fair was visited. At
this point a steamer was taken down the Volga,
numerous stops being made by the party to
examine the geology of the country traversed.
A journey of 1124 miles was made in this manner, the party leaving the boat at Tzaritzin,
and thence proceeding by rail across the
steppes of Central and Southern Russia to
Vladikavkaz.
The Caucasus Mountains were crossed by
the Russian military road in carriages, and
under escort of a Cossack guard. Four days
were consumed upon this journey, all other
traffic across the highway being suspended by
order of the Russian Government. Arriving at
Tiflis, the Capital of Georgia, several days were
spent in examining this wonderful city and its
immediate surroundings. Numerous festivities were arranged by the residents in honor of
their guests.

STUDENT LIFE AT EDINBURGH.
I.
In the university city of Edinburgh a "Town
and Gown Association" was formed in the
year 1896 for co-operative undertakings in the
joint interest of citizens and students. It was
for the common good of city and university.
The Association is a stock company representing academic interests for the purpose of providing residential halls or house accommodation for students and other persons connected
either with the University or with the liberal
professions. Although Edinburgh University
has been in existence for more than two centuries, it has never enjoyed the benefit of college
halls or hostels like those which have given
such architectural character and social charm
to Oxford and Cambridge. Students and professors have lived in Edinburgh wherever they
could find lodgings. There has been no real
unity to academic life, no college centre or
Latin Quarter, where students live and educate
one another in their own society—perhaps the
most effective of all academic means of culture.
The English colleges have always been strong
in social education, but here the Scotch and
German universities are weak.
To remedy a long-standing and manifest defect in Edinburgh student life the Town and
Gown Association was organized by the
energy and enterprise of Professor Patrick
Geddes, who lives near the Outlook Tower on
Castle Hill and surveys from his charming
apartments, at the top of an airy citadel, the
historic City of Edinburgh and the picturesque
country round about. While Professor Geddes
has had in mind the need of better associated
collegiate life in Edinburgh, he has also sought
the material and architectural improvement of
the city. It is well known by all visitors to this
ancient capital of Scotland that the historic and

No. 3

picturesque old town, extending from Castle
Hill eastward to Holyrood, was until lately the
most dilapidated and unsanitary part of the city.
Municipal and architectural improvements,
which Professor Geddes has greatly promoted,
have now transformed some of the worst of
'those ancient rookeries, narrow passageways
and noisome courts into spacious college halls
and modern apartment houses.
The beginnings of this remarkable movement, which is at once "civic and academic,
architectural and educational," date from the
year 1887. Then a new social life was instituted for students in Edinburgh by the renting
and furnishing of three small flats on the socalled "Mound," which connects Old and New
Town. At first only seven students entered
upon this common or associated life ; but the
number increased and soon an entire house was
needed to supply the demand. By a perfectly
natural law of growth, and upon a sound business basis, the first residential hall in Edinburgh was established. It is now a studenthome for members of New College. In 1890
another house WaS purchased in Riddle's court
and reconstructed for student-residents. In
the same year was acquired an historic locality
once occupied by the Scotch poet, Allan Ramsay, author of "The Gentle Shepherd." Gradually a range of new houses was built on two
sides of Ramsay Garden, so that now there is a
large number of comfortable flats, or sets of
chambers, occupied by professors and their
families, and a large building called "Ramsay
Lodge," with numerous rooms, occupied by
students in residence.
The visitor in Edinburgh as he strolls along
Princes street (said to be, for noble views, the
finest street in Europe) will find himself looking upwards to that natural acropolis where
"Edwin's Burgh" gave name and fame to the
Old Town on the hill. Extending eastward
from the castle and the walls of the Esplanade

THE NEWS-LETTER.
NEWS OF A FORTNIGHT.
CONORESSIVE SESSION.

The first regular meeting of the Senate,
which was held November 3, was honored by
the presence of Dean Griffin, who expressed
himself as much pleased with the work. The
meeting proved how much practice in debating
is needed by the Senators. Several of the debaters were seized with stage fright, and found
it difficult to speak without stumbling over
words and making awkward pauses. This fault
is common to all beginners, and will surely disappear with practice. Time that might have
been used in debate was lost in calling the roll
and reading the minutes of the previous meeting. Hereafter the roll will be taken silently—
that is, the clerk will simply mark the absence
of members without calling the names. The
minutes will be referred to the Censor. In this
way it will be possible to begin the debate five
minutes after opening the session. As the Senate ages, the members will settle to their work,
and the slight breaches of decorum that mar
the proceedings of any forensic body will be
eliminated. On the whole, the first meeting
of the Senate may be pronounced a success.
The current debate was won by the affirmative,
represented by Messrs. Lucke, Renouf and E.
Smith.
The subject for the next debate is:
"Resolved, That the result of the work of the
present United States Bimetallic Commission
ought to definitely settle the discussion of the
'Silver Question.'"
Senators Fisher, Fitzgerald and R. D. Miller have the affirmative ; Senators Ballard,
Whitehead and Cook the negative.
The first regular meeting of the House of
Representatives was held Wednesday, October 26. Speaker French presided. The use of
a gavel, a valuable old Indian relic, was tendered to the House by Dr. Adams. The Censor announced that Dr. Adams had also given
the use of the Southern History room for the
debaters. The House moved that a vote of
thanks be given to Dr. Adams. The main interest of the meeting centered in the debate :

3

"Resolved, That municipal government be independent of national party lines." The affirmative was taken by Messrs. Smull, Jones,
Ver Planck and M. Jungbluth ; the negative
by Messrs. Mullen, Grimes, Gemmil and Joyner. The House decided on the merits of the
debaters that the negative side had won. The
debate for next time was given to Congressmen Fosnocht, Frank and Greenbaum for the
negative, and Congressmen Levering, Kalb
and Gaddess for the affirmative. In parliamentary law the following appointments were
made: Leader of attack, H. Grimes; leader
of defense, C. Remsen.

nusicAL CLUB'S CONCERT.
The University Banjo and Mandolin Clubs
gave the first concert of the season on Friday
evening, November 5, at Hannah More Academy, near Reisterstown. The trip was made
on a special car over the new Baltimore and
Northern Electric Railroad.
The occasion of the concert was the opening
of Wyman Hall, which was filled by a large audience drawn from Baltimore, Pikesville and
Reisterstown. The clubs played well and were
heartily received by the audience. The new
men give promise of ranking among the best
players in the clubs, and there is no reason
why, under the leadership of Mr. Peters and
with a full attendance at practice, this year's
clubs should not excel those of '93-'94 and
'96-'97, the best in the history of Hopkins.
Mr. Harwood and Mr. Clunet made a great
hit with their new songs.
The vocal parts were ably given by Miss
Starr, the composer of the music of "Veritas
Vos Liberabit," and Mr. Frank Taylor, the
well-known soloist of the club. Mr. Edwin L.
Turnbull gave two selections on the violin.
After the concert there was dancing, kept
up until the men were compelled to leave, carrying with them pleasant memories of the hospitality of Hannah More.
Dr. Hollander, of the Economic Department, has just returned from Europe, where
he served as secretary of the Bimetallic Commission.

TRAINING AND HONOR.
NEW ATHLETIC ASSOCIATION.

One of the best efforts in athletics at Hopkins is the proposed reorganization of the Athletic Association. Up to the present time the
several other athletic societies which have been
independent of it have amounted to nothing.
Each one is simply a name. It is true that they
do choose officials for the teams, but even this
they sometimes do most unwisely. It is a palpable blunder for a body of several delegates to
elect the leader of a team. The team itself
should choose the captain. Another serious
defect in the several associations was that there
was no business responsibility and no authority. In short the manager was the association,
with all rights and abuses thereto appertaining.
The new association should have a constitut.ion which provides for a strong centralization,
and the alumni should be represented. By
bringing all departments of sport under one
government there is the advantage of having a
reliable organization to guide the teams and
the managers. Then we should have such a
rarity as system. All that is necessary in the
association is a representative membership.
Two of the salient features proposed are the
election of the managers by the board of direct-

Unpleasant rumors are going about. It is
said that certain members of the football team
have been smoking. This is a deplorable state
of affairs. It is right for the students to
object. So long as the players keep in good
physical condition there will be sympathy and
support in case of defeat. But if the men do
not train they cannot expect to win, and they
deserve to be "roasted" by the students. We
hope that the reports of the violations of rules
are untrue. In training for a team the adherence to a pledge is a matter of honesty. There
is no absolute prevention if a man cares to
smoke or in any other way violate the rules.
The point to appreciate, then, is that honor is
just as necessary on the football team as in the
examination room, and a violator should be
treated accordingly.

It is interesting to note the prominent part
played in the late election by former Hopkins
students. One graduate, who, while a student
at the Hopkins, impressed everyone by his extremely retiring disposition, stumped New
York City for Low on street corners and from
the back of grocery wagons.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
!ATHLETICS.
ENTHUSIASTIC rtAss METING.
A mass-meeting of the students was held in
Hopkins Hall October 29 to discuss and consider the reorganization of the General Athletic Association. The assembly decided upon
two points, which, it is believed, will further
the interest of athletics at the University. An
effort will be made to centralize the several
athletic associations which now exist, each
under separate government, and, second, the
students will earnestly strive to procure a field.
President Edward Renouf was chairman
and Dr. J. B. Crenshaw was secretary. The
President discussed the situation of the separate organizations, and showed clearly that unless these associations were put under one head
athletics at the University could never have a
future.
At present there exist the Football Association, the Lacrosse Association, and the Baseball Association. Several speeches were made,
all proving that these several organizations
could no longer exist as such. It was shown
that the associations had done almost nothing
for athletics; that they were mere paper associations, and, beyond assembling for the annual
election of the managers and captains, did absolutely nothing. The responsibility rested
alone on these men, and, if debts were incurred, they alone received the blame.
To obviate this, it was decided that the President appoint a committee of seven students to
ascertain how the students felt on this point,
and to draw up a constitution for the proposed
reorganization.
The committee consists of J. 13. Crenshaw
(chairman), Hancock, Reese, Dieffenbach,
Scholl,'Grimes, G. C. Robinson and Foster.
The heavy beams which will support the
roof of the cage are in position and the building now gives an idea of what it will be when
finished. It will require only a few weeks to
complete the structure. The gymnasium will
not be ready for occupancy so early on account of the interior work.

VICTORIES AT GEORGETOWN.

Johns Hopkins won two events and got second place in another at the Georgetown games
on Saturday. Robert Garrett was the chief attraction of the day, and his feat with the
discus brought out much applause. Scholl
won the high jump, Garrett won at discusthrowing,and was second in the running broad
jump. Knapp was put in a preliminary heat
with Wefers, champion of the world, in the
ioo-yard dash, and failed to qualify in the
final. In the discus event Garrett did not exert
himself, and won easily at 107 feet 7 inches.
Scholl cleared 5 feet 5 inches in the high jump
in good form. In the running broad jump the
measuring was decidedly favorable to Georgetown. When Garrett and Scholl jumped the
tape was drawn taut, but the home competitor,
Walsh, was given a slack tape twisted several
times. The event was nevertheless a notable
one, for Garrett broke the Maryland record
made by him-2I feet 91 inches. He beat this
by an inch and a half. Scholl made 21 feet
inches, breaking his own record by eighteen
inches. Walsh was credited with 22 feet
inch. About forty rooters went over to cheer
on the men. Incidentally, they gave .the other
colleges represented a few pointers as to college yells.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
IN THE LAND OF THE CZAR.
Dr. William B. Clark, professor of geology
in the Johns Hopkins University, has just returned from Russia, where he has been in attendance upon the International Geological
Congress in St. Petersburg. He bore the credentials of the Secretary of State as one of the
six national delegates from the United States,
and also an appointment from the Governor
of Maryland to represent the State as State
Geologist.
An international congress is held every three
years at one of the leading cities of the world,
the first congress being held in Paris in 1878.
Subsequent congresses have been held at Bologna, Berlin, London, Washington and Zurich. The invitation to hold the seventh Inter1Lati9nal Congress at St. Petersburg was presented in the name of the Czar by the Russian
representatives at the Washington Congress
in 1891, and was at once accepted by that Congress. Assurances were given of most cordial
welcome on the part of the Russian Government and people. How sincerely these assurances were meant is shown by the marvelous
hospitality with which the delegates to the International Congress at St. Petersburg were
greeted. Free tickets upon all Russian transportation lines were granted to the members of
the Congress, so that after reaching the borders of Russia no expenses for railway and
steamboat travel were incurred. Orders were
also given to the customs officials to pass the
members of the Congress without inconvenience.
The Congress opened upon August 29 in
St. Petersburg, with somewhat over 600 delegates in attendance, representatives being present from nearly every country of the world.
The Germans and French were much more
numerous than the representatives of other
countries. About forty American geologists
were present, among them the aged Professor
Hall, the State Geologist of New York; Professor Marsh, of Yale University, and Professor S. F. Emmons,of the United States Geological Survey.

7

Among the distinguished Europeans were
Sir Archibald Geikie, who lectured at the University on the Williams foundation last spring;
Baron von Richthofen, of Berlin; Prof. von
Zittel, of Munich ; Professor Zirkel, of Leipsic ; Professor Capellini, of Florence ; Professor Brogger, of Christiania, and many others.
The Congress was opened with an addres by
the Grand Duke Constantine, a cousin of the
Czar, and remained in session a week, during
which time the delegates were elaborately entertained, the Czar giving a great banquet in
honor of the Congress at Peterhof. The members of the Congress were also elaborately entertained by the Grand Duke Constantine, the
Governor of St. Petersburg, and the other
celebrities. During the session of the Congress
the members visited Finland at the invitation of
the Senate of that country, a day being spent at
the Falls of Imatra, where a state dinner was
given in honor of the visitors.
At the close of the Congress the members
went to Moscow, where, after a few days' visit
in that city, they divided into three groups,
each party journeying to Vladikavkaz at the
base of the Caucasus Mountains by different
routes. Professor Clark accompanied the
Volga party, going first to Nijni Novgorod,
where the great Russian fair was visited. At
this point a steamer was taken down the Volga,
numerous stops being made by the party to
examine the geology of the country traversed.
A journey of 1124 miles was made in this manner, the party leaving the boat at Tzaritzin,
and thence proceeding by rail across the
steppes of Central and Southern Russia to
Vladikavkaz.
The Caucasus Mountains were crossed by
the Russian military road in carriages, and
under escort of a Cossack guard. Four days
were consumed upon this journey, all other
traffic across the highway being suspended by
order of the Russian Government. Arriving at
Tiflis, the Capital of Georgia, several days were
spent in examining this wonderful city and its
immediate surroundings. Numerous festivities were arranged by the residents in honor of
their guests.
